title: Impacts of Soil Degradation on Herbivore Populations: A Causal Analysis
abstract: Degradation of terrestrial habitats, particularly through the mechanism of soil erosion, has been hypothesized to influence local fauna negatively. This study explores the extent to which accelerated soil erosion contributes to the decline of herbivore populations. Utilizing longitudinal environmental and ecological data collected over a span of twenty years across various geographic landscapes, we employ statistical models to identify causal relationships between soil degradation and fluctuations in herbivore numbers. Our findings indicate a significant and detrimental impact of increased soil erosion on the availability of essential forage, which in turn has led to noticeable declines in herbivore populations. This relationship holds even after controlling for other potential confounding factors such as climate change, predation pressures, and human encroachment. The study underscores the critical need for sustainable land management practices to mitigate soil erosion with the aim of conserving herbivore populations at risk. The implications of these findings for conservation biology and land management policies are discussed extensively, providing a basis for addressing both ecological and environmental stability in vulnerable ecosystems.
